item.title: Coronavirus: NHS staff need tests 'twice a week'
item.description: Two leading doctors said regular testing is needed to give patients confidence as the NHS reopens.

item.title: Rashford 'grateful' for Boris Johnson free school meals U-turn
item.description: The Manchester United player spoke to BBC Breakfast about his phone call with Boris Johnson.

item.title: 'Invisible' unpaid carers going hungry in lockdown
item.description: Unpaid carers looking after their parents and relatives are turning to food banks, say researchers.

item.title: The Premier League returns - all you need to know
item.description: BBC Sport provides you with all the information you need ahead of the resumption of the English top-flight.

item.title: New trials planned for cash-stricken communities
item.description: Organisers hope the projects will inform debate over the future of cash at a time when card use in rising.

item.title: The new rules for a safe 'day out'
item.description: Theme parks, museums and leisure attractions are working out how they can re-open safely.

item.title: John Bolton: Trump administration sues to block book
item.description: The Department of Justice says the book, published next week, contains "classified information".

item.title: Coronavirus: Dexamethasone proves first life-saving drug
item.description: Patients should be given the cheap drug without delay, after "fantastic" trial results, experts say.

item.title: Coronavirus: Toilet fears hamper high street return for some
item.description: The stores might be back open but will a lack of available toilets put some shoppers off?

item.title: Stars urge BBC to protect regional current affairs programmes
item.description: Broadcasters from Stephen Fry to Sir Lenny Henry sign a letter urging the BBC not to cut Inside Out.

item.title: Coronavirus: Prince Charles's sense of smell and taste still not back
item.description: The prince discusses his experience with Covid-19 as the royals return to public engagements.

item.title: India-China clash: 20 Indian troops killed in Ladakh fighting
item.description: It is the first deadly skirmish in decades between the two regional powers at their disputed border.

item.title: A Street Cat Named Bob: Stray who inspired series of books dies
item.description: James Bowen wrote six books about his pet Bob who he chanced upon while battling drug addiction.

item.title: The Papers: Win for 'hero' Rashford as 'footie drought' ends
item.description: The PM's U-turn on school meal vouchers over the summer in England dominates many front pages.

item.title: Australian architecture: Two Brisbane skyscrapers repurposed into one
item.description: Two Brisbane skyscrapers are being stitched together to create a new "green" building.

item.title: Coronavirus and how to beat it on the sausage frontline
item.description: Since the pandemic started, this company has been feeding sausages to the nation while keeping Covid-19 at bay. How?

item.title: How our brain is processing the pandemic
item.description: Self-isolation, job loss and fear of Covid-19 are just some factors affecting our mental health.

item.title: Coronavirus: Blackpool Pleasure Beach prepares to reopen
item.description: Blackpool Pleasure Beach is preparing to reopen, but how can visitors stay safe?

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Man Utd star a 'hero' in Wythenshawe
item.description: People in Wythenshawe praise Marcus Rashford for forcing a government U-turn on school meal vouchers.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: 'We all have to do our part in changing things'
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown has given Miguel time to think about how he hopes to change the world.

item.title: Coronavirus: Greggs to reopen 800 shops for takeaway
item.description: Greggs edges towards full reopening while Cineworld cinemas plan to restart screenings in July.

item.title: A Bee C: Scientists translate honeybee queen duets
item.description: Queens "quack" when ready to hatch - but if two are free at the same time, they fight to the death.

item.title: Chronixx: Our generation needs a new type of protest
item.description: Reggae giant Chronixx says the world needs a new type of protest for meaningful change to happen.

item.title: Diego, the Galápagos tortoise with a species-saving sex drive, retires
item.description: Diego, aged 100, returns to his native Galápagos island after decades of breeding in captivity.

item.title: Instagram 'will overtake Twitter as a news source'
item.description: A report finds Instagram doubled its news audience last year - and could overtake Twitter by 2021.

item.title: Coronavirus: What’s it like to start a new job when working remotely?
item.description: With many people working from home due to the coronavirus outbreak, what’s it like to start a new job on a remote team?

item.title: The blogger who hit back against a hammer-wielding Russian ‘assassin’
item.description: Tumso Abdurakhmanov says Russia's security service must have helped Chechens plan an attempt to assassinate him.

item.title: How Elon Musk aims to revolutionise battery technology
item.description: Could the least exciting bit of Elon Musk's empire end up being the most transformative?

item.title: Portugal finally recognises consul who saved thousands from Holocaust
item.description: Eighty years ago a Portuguese consul gave visas to thousands fleeing the invading Nazis in France.

item.title: Why drill music is being used to teach philosophy
item.description: The team behind RoadWorks say people who don't want to conform are "natural social scientists".

item.title: India-China dispute: The border row explained in 400 words
item.description: Here's what you need to know about a border dispute that has turned deadly high in the Himalayas.

item.title: What's behind the PM's aid department decision?
item.description: There is a tension at the heart of the plan to merge the Foreign Office and the department handling overseas aid.

item.title: 'I'm sorry for being racist when I was younger'
item.description: Two young people who were racist when they were younger explain why they have changed.

item.title: George Floyd: Eyewitnesses recount harrowing death
item.description: Panorama spoke to local people to piece together the moments leading up to George Floyd's death.

item.title: 'People queued for an hour to enter' the shop
item.description: As the High Street opens for business, workers tell the BBC what it was like after weeks of lockdown.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: Have racial inequality reviews led to action?
item.description: A number of reviews have looked at race and equality over the years, but has the government taken action?

item.title: Atatiana Jefferson: 'Why I will no longer call the police'
item.description: When James Smith called police to check his neighbour was OK, she ended up dead. Never again, he says.

item.title: The lengths countries go to for a seat at UN top table
item.description: Canada, Norway and Ireland are in a tight race for two non-permanent seats on the security council.

item.title: Navajo Nation: The people battling America's worst coronavirus outbreak
item.description: The challenges of life in the Navajo Nation have made containing Covid-19 even more difficult.

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Food voucher U-turn after footballer's campaign
item.description: The Manchester United star praises the government for agreeing to fund free school meals in England this summer.

item.title: Bayern win eighth consecutive title and celebrate in empty stadium
item.description: Bayern Munich celebrate behind closed doors after beating Werder Bremen to seal an eighth successive Bundesliga title.

item.title: Thorne placed into induced coma in Spain
item.description: Former snooker star Willie Thorne is placed into an induced coma in hospital in Spain after suffering respiratory failure.

item.title: Newcastle deal could be affected as WTO rules Saudi Arabia broke trade rules
item.description: Newcastle United's Saudi Arabian-led takeover could be complicated by a ruling that the country helped breach international piracy laws.

item.title: Wednesday's gossip: Man Utd make contact over Willian free transfer
item.description: Manchester United interested in Willian, Everton pursue Napoli's Allan, plus more.

item.title: US Open to be held behind closed doors after New York governor gives go-ahead
item.description: The US Open can take place without fans from 31 August to 13 September, says governor of New York Andrew Cuomo.

item.title: Euros On This Day - 16 June: NI's GAWA power, Suker's chip & England's late late show
item.description: BBC Sport rounds up the best archive action from 16 June in European Championship history.

item.title: George Floyd death: 'The same happened to my son'
